entry.title: Re: Who can delete draft cases? and How?
entry.content:
Dear customer,

The following S-users can delete Draft cases which have a status of Not Sent to SAP:

  • S-user ID that created the draft case
  • Super Administrators listed in My Important Contacts

Only Super Administrators can delete draft cases for other S-users; Cloud and User Administrators cannot delete draft cases created by other S-users at this time.

Steps to delete a draft case

  1. Go to SAP for Me > Draft Cases
  2. Select the draft case you wish to delete from the list (has a status of Not Sent to SAP)
  3. Click ‚ÄúDelete‚Äù on the upper right
  4. On the Close pop up, click ‚ÄùDelete‚Äú

Also refer to KBA 2594949 - How to delete a draft case - SAP for Me.

And hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: WPDTC tcode calculation of PDT and deviation calculated?
entry.content:
WPDTC analyses historical purchasing documents (POs and their GRs) to calculate an average planned delivery time for a material/vendor combination. It uses the difference between PO creation date and goods receipt date for each document, optionally weighted by the quantity received. The results are shown per purchasing info record (PIR) or other aggregation level, and you can then decide whether to update the Planned Delivery Time in the master data.

The weighting factor used in the average calculation formular would be "Proportion = (Goods Receipt Quantity) √∑ (Purchase Order Quantity)". If you received double the PO quantity like PO was for 100, GR was for 200, the proportion will be 2.0. If you received exactly what you ordered, it will be 1.0. If you received half, it will be 0.5. SAP uses this proportion to weight the delivery time in the average ‚Äî so large deliveries influence the average more than small ones.

Also, WPDTC does not automatically change master data; it only proposes the new value. You can update it in the Purchasing Info Record (EINA/EINE) ‚Üí field Planned Delivery Time. Or, if you don‚Äôt use PIRs, in the Material Master (Purchasing view) ‚Üí field Planned Delivery Time.

entry.title: Re: Role Collection Assignment in Build Work Zone, Standa...
entry.content:
Hi Julius,

I found the solution for this.

We can not create the group in BTP Sub Account level but we can create the groups in SAP Cloud Identity Service and assign the user to the group in SAP CIS.

Now in Subaccount level we can map this group to role collection and the user associated with that group will get the roles.

The Group name will not auto populate in the BTP, we need to copy the group name from CIS to the Role collection mapping.

 

I am marking this as solved.


Regards,

Rohit Gera

entry.title: Re: Role Collection Assignment in Build Work Zone, Standard Edition
entry.content:
Hello Rohit, Yes correct. In addition, you can do one of 2 things depending on whether your idp is azure or IAS. If you have groups defined in your azure idp (or in your corporate IDP), you can map the roles to Azure groups in the sub-account. In that case, the users will see apps based on their Azure groups. Second option is similar to what you were saying in IAS. But instead of manually creating, you could propagate the groups from Azure Active directory to your IAS and from IAS to BTP. The groups will not appear in the sub account but the users will have access to the apps. Just like magic üôÇ Glad you figured this out by going the IAS route. 

The second advantage of this route (azure or IAS) is that when user are no longer with the company and are terminated in the IDP, they automatically lose access to build work zone. So no additional work is needed during terminations.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Integration: How to use Password Credentials for Outbound Request
entry.content:
Hi Ankur,

This thread is old, but maybe someone will encounter the same error: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Access Token was not found in the response

The reason is that the Access Token is not being returned to be used for accessing REST API Destinations. This is most likely the result of not providing the correct Token URL in Security Material - Client Credentials. Info about this was missing in Carlos article and first I put there wrong URL... The correct URL is the URI taken from the service key + /oauth/token path, so the full URL would be something like this:

https://<subdomain>.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

entry.title: BI 4.3 Report / Universe Metadata missing for unchanged migrated reports
entry.content:
Hi there

A customer of mine needs to change Web Intelligence Report queries in their BI 4.3 system from an old set of universes to a new set, which I intend to do using the Workflow Manager. To assist with this, we are trying to establish all of the reports that use those old universes.

These methods can be used to establish the universe/report relationships without actually opening and looking at the reports themselves:

1) Right-click on a universe, choose Tools > Check Relationships

That gives you a list of files that relate to that universe, including folders, connection objects and reports.

2) Open the properties of a report and Choose "Default Settings" > "Report Universes". That gives a list of universes used in that report.

3) Use the CMS Universe that is now provided with the system, which looks at the same data.

However... what I'm finding, and I've found with other systems, is that the above works for all reports that have been created or amended on that system. For those reports which haven't been amended since being migrated to the system from a different system (typically older system), this metadata is missing. So reports might be scheduled or opened and refreshed, but if the report isn't saved back, then that data is missing.

For example - a report which was migrated to the current BI 4.3 system, from the previous BI 4.2 system the customer used (using Promotion Management Wizard) shows the following when its properties are opened in the CMC:

If I then open the report in Design mode, make a trivial change (such as adding a space to the Description object in the properties) and then saving the report back to the Input File Repository, it then updates the meta data.

Opening the report's properties in the CMC and amending the properties there doesn't do this, it actually requires the file itself to be changed.

Now this customer has many thousands of reports in public and personal folders. I don't want to have to open every single file to work out which reports use the universes in question, I would like to be able to use the report I've built which uses the CMS universe. That CMS report works for all those reports which have been created and changed since their content was migrated there, but the unchanged reports are missing.

Does anyone have any ideas of methods that could be used to force the system's meta-data to be updated for all reports automatically? I wondered if there was something in the Workflow Assistant but I don't think there is (and that in itself is somewhat cumbersome to use albeit the best solution for tasks such as universe query repointing).

Thanks very much

entry.title: Re: TIMEOUT dump (11 min.) for RFC in low priority (runti...
entry.content:
Oh nice, I didn't even look at the P_TIMEOUT parameter. So, if I debug my case, CL_ABAP_PARALLEL takes the priority of the current session (high if it's running in dialog, low if it's running in background) and so it considers correctly the timeout. SM50 always shows "Low" but it doesn't mean the timeout, as said in the dump, the timeout may be set by the application which is the case here. By looking at inside the function module RS_ABAP_PARALLEL_INST, one can see the way an application can set the timeout (number of seconds):

data(L_RUNT_TIME) = CL_RUNTIME_FACTORY=>CREATE( ).
L_RUNT_TIME->SET_MAX_RUNTIME( P_TIME_OUT ).

entry.title: Re: C_S4CPB_2502 Dumps valid or Not?
entry.content:
Hello @brettskipp4311 

Using dumps is neither valid nor officially supported for preparing for SAP certifications. They often have outdated or incorrect information, and SAP‚Äôs exam policies ban their use. A better approach is to gain knowledge through authorised learning resources and practical experience.

Here is a recommended study path for C_S4CPB_2502 (SAP Certified Associate ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Implementation with SAP Activate):

Understand the core concepts
 Explore the Learning Journey: Exploring Localisation as a Self-Service

Hands-on practice
Apply the knowledge in the Applying Localisation as a Self-Service course

Configuration and CBC focus
Enrol for Central Business Configuration (CBC) and localisation training, since CBC setup and country activation are key areas tested in this exam.

Deep dive into documentation & SAP Community
 Review SAP Help Portal: Localisation and Scope

Practice with sample questions
Use SAP‚Äôs official sample questions and reputable practice tests to familiarise yourself with the exam style (erpprep), but avoid dumps.

This approach guarantees you not only pass the exam but also acquire the knowledge to apply in real-world applications.

Happy to answer any further questions you might have.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) - Climate Action : Corporate Carbon Footprint Calculation(CCF)
entry.content:
This blog outlines the steps involved in tracking and managing emissions from various business activities within different locations to get insights on environmental analysis using "Climate Action" application in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT).

üåèThe earth speaks in colors, whispers in winds, and sings through rivers ‚Äî if only we choose to listen‚Ä¶üå±

What is Climate Action?

It is the heartbeat of Goal 13 in the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals and one of the three main pillars of UNEP (United Nations Environment Programme). Climate Action is taking efforts to tackle climate change and reduce its impacts and adapt to the changes it causes.

SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Climate Action functionality  supports organizations to set up Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) feature to calculate their sustainability footprint. This feature facilitates the organizations to setup the data  for business activities (for example, Business Travel, Employee Commute) for each respective "Business Location" and calculate the carbon footprint using emission factors in the SAP SCT system.

Mini Note: This feature is distinct from "Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics". Both the functionalities are meant for collection of data via forms, but the apps, user roles and workflow are different from each other. To be able to use Climate Action - Corporate Carbon Footprint (CCF) calculations directly in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT), we must run the "Booster" scenario from the SAP BTP cockpit.

Process Overview:

Overall Process Flow

Before we dive into the SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Climate Action process steps, and as part of the Climate Action awareness program, I would like to highlight a few key aspects of the Climate Action...

Did you know that tiny Sand Bubbler Crabs teach us about Climate Adaptation through their behavior?...

Very recently I had a chance to visit one of the coastal places surrounded by the Arabian Sea.  When I was strolling on the beach, a sand bubbler crab behavior caught my attention. I wondered why on earth such a tiny species would make a sand balls, then immediately I took my phone and sat down near its hole and started recording it...as soon as it noticed me, immediately it went into its hole and did not come back for a while...but I was waiting patiently without a movement...finally I captured the sand bubbler behavior. I was wondering why would it do so, and It taught me a big lesson...

Sand Bubbler Crab...

The Sand Bubbler Crabs are nature`s micro-recyclers and beach`s secret engineers. They make holes for their shelter and safety. When it comes to their feeding strategy, they pick up the sand and filter out the tiny chunks of organic matter and discard the sand in the form of tiny sand balls. Some crabs use sand balls as a barriers to confuse predators. This behavior help clean the coastal area and contribute to the health of beach ecosystems. These carbs adjust their activity based on temperature and tidal conditions. This is a survival strategy in extreme environmental conditions. This is what we should learn from Sand Bubbler Crabs for adaptability of Climate Change. The crab`s feeding process is a natural example of Circular Economy - Extract the organic matter from the sand and leave the sand in the form of balls and repeat the process each time when the tide returns. Their Presence or absence signals the shift in coastal climate patterns.

Though the act is very small, it is so vital. Climate action begins just like that...a mindful step. 

We have been witnessing the consequences of climate change...but, despite knowing the visible consequences, we continue to stall the efforts to combat climate change and adaptation measures...     Source: UNDP website

Climate Change is Increasing ocean and atmospheric temperatures, and due to which the sea levels are going up and as a result, the frequency of hurricanes, rainfall rates are increasing...

If you want to gain a deeper understanding of SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT), check out my blog links below for more insights...

  1. SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Generate ESG Reports With AI Application 
  2. Managing Qualitative Metrics in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) for ESRS and BRSR Framework 
  3. Exporting and Importing Custom Objects and CPE Packages in SAP Sustainability Control Tower 
  4. Achieving Sustainability With SAP Asset Performance Management By Leveraging Industrial Systems. 
  5. SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) Metric Management-Basic Custom Metric & Standard Custom Metric 
  6. SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHS Environment Management 
  7. Addendum to SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHSM-EM 
  8. European Sustainability Reporting Standards(ESRS) Journey With SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) 

Let us dive into our SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) and see how we can steer the organization`s carbon footprint for each business activity...

Prepare Master Data:

For demonstration purpose, I have chosen the location "Louisiana".

Maintain Emission Factor:

Emission Factors are used in the calculation of Carbon Footprint for different business activities. The default data package is available for use from the US EPA (United States Environmental Protection Agency). If an organization has its own emission factor dataset, it can be used for their carbon footprint calculations by creating a "Custom Dataset".

 

 

 

Manage Business Activities:

A business activity can be any organizational activity used to calculate emissions. For example, I have chosen the business activities listed below. 

For Instance, I have chosen "Business Travel by Company Owned EV".

Now let us assign the emission factor Dataset from the default emission factor reference packages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Manage GHG Data Collection or Record GHG Data:                                         

  

 

 

 

 

We can use either one app to record GHG Data values in the forms.

For Instance, let us use the app "Manage GHG Data Collections" to create GHG Emission data collection strategy for the location "Louisiana" for the period "May,2024".

For Instance, let us create the data collection strategy for the period "May, 2024".

The GHG Data Forms table shows all the locations that are included in the collection. We can exclude any locations by selecting the location and choosing the option "Not Applicable". We can also undo it by selecting the location in the Not Applicable Tab and choosing the option "Reopen".

For Instance, I have chosen the location "Louisiana".

 

 

Record GHG Data:

Now let us enter the GHG data for the location "Louisiana" using  "Record GHG Data" app.

Once we have updated the field values, set the collection data status as "Completed".

 

Now the entered GHG Data will be reviewed by a designated person to confirm that it is ready for reporting.

Note that the "Reviewer" has to provide the comments.

Now the status will be changed to "reviewed", and the data is published to the "View Emissions Data" app.

 

What If the organization adds a new business activity after reviewing the GHG Data for the defined periods?

SAP has provided an option called "Regenerate". This option is used to regenerate the data collection after changes have been made.

For Instance, I have created a new business activity, i.e., Diesel Consumption for 550 KVA DG Set. This activity falls under Scope-1, Stationary Combustion.

 

Now let us assign the emission factor. I have chosen Quantity Based Calculation.

 

 

Following the successful creation of business activity, we have to come back to "Manage GHG Data Collections" app , then select the relevant collection or even multiple collections  and choose the option "Regenerate".

For Instance I have chosen the collection for periods July 2025 & August 2025.

The status of the collections changes to "In progress" and system generates the data forms for those collections again.

Now let us update the field values and review the data collection using "Record GHG Data" app for the periods July, 2025 & August, 2025.

Now we can update the status to  "Completed" .

 

 

We can now "Review" and update the status to "Reviewed" using "GHG Data Collections" app.

 

 

View Emission Dashboard:

Following the successful recording and review of the Business Activity Data, we can now visualize the overall emissions data for the location using the View Emission Dashboard app.

Emissions Report

 

Emissions Analytics

 

üòäThis concludes the walkthrough of the "SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Climate Action" process. I hope my blog serves as a useful resource for the environmental management team. Stay tuned for more updates on SAP SCT.

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy.C

entry.title: Re: How to set up FOC subcontracting process, without bot...
entry.content:
Hello @Deepika8 

Thanks for sharing the additional information. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, a material ID and system stock availability are required to complete the delivery and post goods issue. Without these, the standard steps cannot be executed.

Here are a few possible approaches to consider:

Generic or non-valued materials: Create a generic material master Returnable Packaging or Calibration Equipment so you have at least a material ID for logistics documents.

Non-stock or service materials: If you only need document flow and not full inventory tracking, non-stock/service material types might meet your needs..

Scope item 3W3 (Advanced Returns Management): Worth reviewing if the process is closer to a customer/vendor return scenario.Executing and Running Customer Returns Management (BKP)-SAP Learning

Custom extension (SAP BTP): If dealing with items without material IDs and stock is a strict requirement, this might suggest a lightweight extension rather than the standard stock-relevant flow.

For the standard RDN/MSDN process in Public Cloud, a material ID and stock in the system are required. If these are not available, you‚Äôll need to model the flow differently using one of the alternatives mentioned above.

Let me know if you need further assistance

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Time off Finland - accrual rules and best practices package
entry.content:
Dear community, 

I'm coming to ask if there are customers actually being able to work with Time off in Finland, and having the accrual rules working correctly in the cases of parental leaves.. I've been checking the best practices solution deployed in 1H 2024 but this solution does not seem to fulfill the legal requirements. 1H 2024 Release Highlights of SAP Best Practices f... - SAP Community

@NeeleshKamath 

I've been working with a Finnish customer which claims the following legal requirement: Per child, the employee accumulates holidays for a maximum of 160 days of parental leave. This count is made Monday to Saturday. The moment the employee reaches that limit, he stops accumulating holidays in the months he is still absent due to the same child birth. The employee can take the parental leave until the child becomes 2 years old. 

This needs to work together with the Finnish 14 days rule : an employee accumulates holidays for a certain month as long as he has worked at least 14 days in a month. That can be controlled with rule functions "Get Number Of Working Days Or Hours For Period()" from accruable start date to accruable end date. (OK until there)

So what the Best Practices rule (SFCC_ACC_FIN_Holiday_Credit_Accruals)  does is the following: count parental leaves in deduction quantity up to 160 days (monday to saturdays), and from that moment, penalize the employee. In a month, we will get the working days MINUS the days above 160 to see if it is above/below 14 days for the accrual. This solution is never considering which child the absence is about (what if you have multiple children?) and never considering the 2 years period mentioned above (it is checking the 160 limit in the year). 

As a result: this would never work well in reality!

For example imagine an employee has parental leave (reaching 160 days) on the 28th of June 2025, and he is on parental leave until the 12th of july (Saturday).

According to the Best Practices rule, the working days in july are 23. 

The days exceeding 160 days are from the 1st of july until the 12th (in yellow), saturdays included = 11

23 minus 11 = 12 days. 12 days is below 14 days, so the employee should not be eligible to accumulate holidays in that month. 

But in reality the employee should accumulate holidays because: 

Working days = 23

Working Days absent due to parental leave = 9

23 minus 9 = 14 days. Equal or above to the 14 days limit. so he would accrue days for that month. 

The difference is mixing units: working days vs deduction quantity. And deduction quantity days could be even greater than the working days!

So, seriously, has any company been able to work with this successfully?

 

Thank you very much for your time

Laura

entry.title: Re: Handling inventory updates from EWM to S/4HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
Hi Lakshmipathi,

Dear SAP Support,

I would like to reopen this ticket with additional information regarding the handling of inventory differences (physical inventory postings) in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Üî decentralized EWM integration (scope item 7L1).

Current Situation

  • We are running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integrated with a decentralized EWM system.

  • Standard logistics flows work correctly: inbound deliveries, outbound deliveries, pick denial/short-pick quantities are properly reflected back into S/4 via goods issue confirmation.

  • However, physical inventory (PI) differences posted in EWM are not replicated to S/4, which causes stock discrepancies between the two systems.

SAP‚Äôs Previous Suggestion
We received the advice that PI differences could be forwarded via Boomi/CPI using an API.

Why this does not work in our scenario

  • In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the only relevant API for posting stock adjustments is API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV.

  • Direct posting of goods movements (e.g. 701/702) via this API works for non-EWM storage locations.

  • But for EWM-managed storage locations, S/4 requires all postings to come through deliveries confirmed by EWM. Direct goods movement postings on those locations are not accepted.

  • This means that forwarding PI differences from EWM to S/4 via Boomi/CPI and calling API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV will not update stock in S/4, as the postings are rejected for EWM-managed storage locations.

Conclusion / Clarification Requested

  • The current 7L1 scope does not support replication of PI differences from decentralized EWM to S/4 Public Cloud.

  • The suggested workaround (Boomi/CPI calling an API) cannot function for EWM-managed storage locations.

Request
Could you please confirm:

  • Is there any supported or planned method in S/4 Public Cloud ‚Üî decentralized EWM integration to replicate PI differences to S/4?

  • If not, can SAP officially confirm that this is out of scope and must be solved with a custom extension, for example a customizing or enhancement in EWM that is triggered by a posting in the Difference Analyzer and automatically creates and sends an adjustment delivery to S/4?

Thank you for your clarification.

entry.title: Re: Old Supplier invoice not created with reference to in...

entry.title: Re: New Pipeline Concept features: new partner id definition, alternative partner, bypass option
entry.content:
@mdhira I was about to update the script but then figured out that you could run your P2P scenario on Edge Integration Cell already today, you just have to define a header partnerID in your scenario-specific inbound flow, this header is passed to the generic outbound flow, and when set your script won't fail. Usually this header holds the configuration scenario name and is used to call the Partner Directory, in your case you don't need it to call the Partner Directory but to ensure that the script won't fail, so you can choose any value.

Some background:

I intended to change this part assuming that when running the script on Edge Integration Cell, the service will be null, and if null I would then skip all the rest of the code. However, I just learned that although the Partner Directory is not supported yet on Edge, the Partner Directory tables already exist on Edge and hence this script will never throw an exception.

def service = ITApiFactory.getApi(PartnerDirectoryService.class, null);
if (service == null){
throw new IllegalStateException("Partner Directory Service not found");
}

So, the reason why the script fails is this part where we throw an error if partnerID is not set which is the case for P2P scenarios where you directly store the message in the last JMS queue PIPQ04 bypassing the main pipeline.

// get pid
def headers = message.getHeaders();
def Pid = headers.get("partnerID");
if (Pid == null){
throw new IllegalStateException("Partner ID not found in sent message");
}

So, to run P2P scenario without involving the main pipeline, you need to define the following headers in the scenario-specific inbound flow:

  • SAP_OutboundProcessingEndpoint with value ProcessDirect end point of your scenario-specific outbound flow
  • partnerID with any value
  • optionally: maxJMSRetries to reduce the number of attempts to restart failed messages

Long term we can make the script more robust so that it also works without the partnerID but for the time being you are not blocked. We also think about to support more use cases by maintaining more parameters in the scenario-specific inbound flows so that the Partner Directory doesn't need to be called and hence more scenarios can be run on Edge as long as the Partner Directory is not supported on Edge.

Alex

entry.title: Developing Processes in SAP Build Process Automation for Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) is SAP‚Äôs new low-code/no-code platform that replaces Business Application Studio (BAS) for workflow development. With SBPA, workflows can be modeled, automated, and integrated visually, making it easier to connect business processes with collaboration scenarios.

In this article, we will walk through the complete journey: creating your first process in SBPA, deploying and running it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). You can follow the step-by-step instructions together with the screenshots to easily reproduce each step on your own system.

To get started, you need two prerequisites: a properly configured SBPA environment and an existing IPD Collaboration. Guidance for setting up Collaboration can be found in the official SAP Help for IPD Collaboration, while instructions for preparing SBPA are available in the SBPA Setup Guide.

 

Build you first Process

Step 1: Create a New Project

When you first log in to SAP Build Process Automation, you will see the Welcome to SAP Build page. Since there are no projects available yet, you need to start by creating a new one.

  1. Go to the All Projects section.
  2. Click on the Create button (highlighted in the top-right corner).

Step 2: Select the Project Type

In the Create Project wizard, you first need to define the objective of your project.

  1. Choose Automated Process (the middle option).
    • This option allows you to build process automations using drag-and-drop simplicity within SAP Build.
    • After selecting Automated Process, click Next to proceed.

Step 3: Choose the Development Type

After defining the objective, you now select the type of development configuration for your project.

  1. You will see two options:
    • Process ‚Äì Build a business process to automate a workflow (e.g., sales order automation, invoice management, approval flows).
    • Automation ‚Äì Automate repetitive tasks across applications (e.g., robotic process automation for manual tasks).
  2. For this tutorial, select Process.
    • This option enables you to design complete workflows with multiple steps, approvals, and integrations.
  3. Once selected, click Next to proceed to the project setup.

Step 4: Define the Project Name and Description

Next, you need to provide a meaningful name and description for your project. This will help you and your team easily identify the purpose of the process later.

  1. In the Name field, enter a clear and descriptive title for your project.
  2. In the Description field, provide additional details about the project‚Äôs purpose or scope.
  3. Once completed, click Review to proceed to the summary step.

Step 5: Review and Create the Project

The final step of the project creation wizard is to review your configuration before creating the project.

  1. The Summary page displays an overview of your selections:
    • Objective
    • Type
    • Name
    • Description
  2. Carefully check that all information is correct.
    • If needed, use the Edit links to make adjustments.
  3. Once everything looks good, click Create (bottom-right corner).

Your new project will now be generated, and you will be taken to the project workspace where you can start designing and automating your business process.

‚ÄÉ

Step 6: Create a New Process

After creating the project, the next step is to define your first process inside it.

  1. In the Create Process dialog, provide the following details:
    • Name*: Enter a clear and descriptive process name.
    • Identifier*: Automatically filled
    • Description: Optionally, add a short description explaining the purpose of the process.
  2. Once all required fields are filled out, click Create.

Your process will be added to the project, and you can now begin designing the workflow by adding triggers, actions, and automation steps.

Step 7: Define a Process Trigger

Every process in SAP Build needs a trigger to define how it will start.

  1. Add a Trigger.
  2. In the Trigger configuration, you will see multiple options:
    • Submit a Form ‚Äì The process starts when a user submits a predefined form.
    • API Trigger ‚Äì The process is started by an external system or application through an API call.
    • Wait for an Event ‚Äì The process begins when a specific event occurs.
    • Scheduled Trigger ‚Äì The process runs automatically on a defined schedule.
  3. To use BPA with IPD, select API Trigger.
    • This option allows your process to be called programmatically by IPD.
  4. Select a name for your Trigger

 

Step 8: Configure Process Variables

To make your process dynamic, you need to define variables such as inputs, outputs, or custom fields. These variables allow data to flow through the process.

  1. Open the Process Details panel by clicking the side arrow button on the right hand side of the screen.
  2. Navigate to the Variables tab.
  3. Under Process Inputs, click Configure to define the data that your process should receive when triggered.
    • Process Inputs: Data passed into the process when it starts (e.g., order ID, customer name).
    • Process Outputs: Data that the process returns after execution.
    • Custom Variables: Additional internal variables you can use within the process flow.

 

Step 9: Define Process Inputs for BPA‚ÄìIPD Connection

In order to establish the connection between BPA and IPD, you must configure the Process Inputs exactly as shown. These inputs are required for the API trigger to pass data correctly into the process.

  1. Open the Configure Process Inputs dialog.
  2. Add the following two inputs:

Important: If these inputs are not configured correctly, the API trigger will not be able to pass the required values, and the integration with IPD will fail.

  • Name: Subject
    • Identifier: subject
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Name: Business Key
    • Identifier: businessKey
    • Description
    • Type: String
  • Make sure that both fields are created exactly with these Names and Identifiers.
    • The Identifier values (subject, businessKey) are case-sensitive and must match exactly to ensure proper data exchange with IPD.

Once everything is set, click Apply.

Step 10: Bind Process Inputs to the Process Details

After creating the required inputs (Subject and Business Key), you must bind them to the process definition so that they are recognized and used by BPA when triggered.

  1. Close and reopen the Process Details Panel.
  2. In the Process Content panel (on the left), expand Process Inputs.
    • You should see the variables Business Key and Subject listed.
  3. In the Process Details section (on the right):
    • Bind the Subject input variable, or
    • Enter a custom text string (e.g., IPD Process).
    • For the Subject field, you can either:
    • For the Business Key field, you must bind the Business Key input variable.

Important:

  • The Business Key is required. It uniquely identifies the process instance with a collaboration room.
  • The Subject is more flexible, it can either use the variable or a static text, depending on how you want the process name to appear in the work items tab of the collaboration room

 

Step 11: Add the First Step to the Process

Now that the trigger and process inputs are defined, you can begin building the workflow by adding steps between the trigger and the end node.

In the process flow, click the ‚Äú+‚Äù symbol between the ProcessTrigger and the End node.

Step 12: Add a Form Step

When you add a step to your process, you can choose from different task types such as Approval, Automation, Email, or Decision.

  1. In the Choose what happens next dialog, select Form.
    • A Form step allows you to create a user-friendly form that can be filled out by process participants.
    • This is ideal for capturing data inputs (e.g., request details, feedback, approvals) at runtime.
  2. After selecting Form, you will be prompted to either:
    • Reuse an existing form already available in the project, or
    • Create a new blank form from scratch.

In this tutorial, we will continue by selecting Blank Form to design a new one.

Step 13: Configure the Form Step

Once the Form has been added to your process, you need to configure its general settings and assign key properties.

  1. In the Form step configuration panel (right side), define the following:
    1. Step Name: A descriptive name for the form step (e.g., MyTestForm).
  2. Set the required fields
    • Subject*:
    • Description: Optionally add a short explanation for the form‚Äôs purpose.
    • Priority*: Select the task priority (e.g., Low, Medium, High).
    • Users: Enter individual user mails, seperated by a comma.
    • Groups: Assign the task to a predefined user group.

Step 14: Open the Form Editor

After configuring the general settings for your form step, you can now design the form itself.

  1. In the Form Step Configuration panel, click Open Editor (next to the Form field).
    • This will open a new tab with the Form Designer where you can add and arrange input fields.

 

Step 15: Design the Form in the Form Editor

Once inside the Form Editor, you can create the layout and define the fields that the user will interact with during the process.

  1. Add and configure form elements:
    • Use the toolbar on the left (Text, Headings, Input fields, Checkboxes, Dropdowns, etc.) to drag components into the form area.
    • In this example, a Text Field labeled Test Data is added as a required field.
    • You can also include links, buttons, or additional sections for richer forms.
  2. Customize the form content:
    • Add a descriptive title or instructions (e.g., Please enter some test data).
    • Define placeholders, default values, and whether a field is mandatory.
  3. Save the form:
    • Once you‚Äôve added and configured your fields, click Save in the top-right corner.

Saving ensures the form is available in your process and can be used in runtime execution.

Step 16: Save the Process

Once the process has been designed, you need to save and then release it to make it executable.

  1. Go back to the process
  2. Save the process
    • Click the Save button (top right corner).
    • This ensures all recent changes including triggers, forms, and variables are stored in the project.

The status will update to Saved.

Step 17: Define the Release Version and Notes

When you release the process, you need to provide versioning information and optionally describe the changes.

  1. In the Release Project dialog, enter the following details:
    • Use semantic versioning:
      • Major (X.0.0) for big new features or breaking changes.
      • Minor (0.X.0) for enhancements or smaller changes.
      • Patch (0.0.X) for bug fixes.
    • Release Version: Define the version number (e.g., 1.0.0).
    • Release Notes: Provide a short summary of the main changes in this version (e.g., Initial release with form input).

Click Release to finalize.

Step 18: Confirm and Deploy the Released Project Version

After releasing the project, SAP Build confirms that the process has been published successfully.

  1. A green confirmation message appears at the top of the screen:
    • Click Show project version to open details of the released version.
  2. In the Project Version Overview, you can review:
    • The artifacts (e.g., IPD Process, MyTestForm).
    • The triggers that start the process.
    • The dependencies, if any.
  3. To make the process executable in your environment, click Deploy (top-right corner).
    • Release makes a version available.

Deploy activates it so the process can actually be triggered (via UI or API).

Step 19: Confirm Deployment and Trigger Creation

When deploying a project version, SAP Build will inform you about the effect on triggers.

  1. In the Effect on Triggers dialog, you can see which triggers will be created or updated.
    • In this example: ProcessTrigger ‚Üí Will be created.
  2. Click Deploy to confirm.
    • This activates the trigger and makes the process executable in your environment.

Once deployed, external systems (like IPD) can call this trigger via API to start the process.

Step 20: Verify the Deployment Status

After deployment, you can confirm that your process is active and ready to run.

  1. In the Project Overview, the status indicators will show:
    • Deployed ‚Üí The process version has been successfully deployed.
    • Active ‚Üí The process is currently live and can be triggered.

Step 21: Switch to IPD

Once your process is deployed and active in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA), you can continue with the integration in IPD (Integrated Product Development).

Step 22: Open Workflow Properties in IPD

To connect your deployed BPA process with IPD, you first need to configure the workflow properties.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the tile Workflow Properties.

Click on Workflow Properties to open the configuration settings

Step 23: Create a Workflow Property for the BPA Process in IPD

Workflow Properties in IPD allow you to define additional technical parameters for integrating and controlling your process.

  1. In the Workflow Properties overview, click Create.
  2. In the Create Workflow Property dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select your BPA workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Workflow Property*: Enter a property name.
    • Property Value: Define the value to be used for this property.
    • Property Value Description: (Optional) Add a description to make the property easier to understand.
  3. Additional options:
    • Assign Users to Business Role: Links the property to specific business roles.
    • Default Property Value: Provides a fallback if no value is passed at runtime.
    • Allow Changes at Runtime: Enable this if the property should be overwritten during execution.
  4. Click Save to create the workflow property.

Step 24: Open Configure Collaboration in IPD

To finalize the integration and ensure that your BPA process can be executed within IPD, you need to configure collaboration settings.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, locate the Configure Collaboration tile.
  2. Click on Configure Collaboration.

Step 25: Define a New Collaboration Type in IPD

To connect your BPA process with a collaboration, you must create a new collaboration type.

  1. In the New Collaboration Type dialog, provide the following details:
    • ID*: A unique identifier for this collaboration type (e.g., BACT).
    • Description*: A descriptive name (e.g., Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
    • Purpose: (Optional) Enter the business purpose of this collaboration type.
    • Status: Initially set to In Preparation.
  2. Under General Information:
    • Status Profile*: Select a profile that defines the process status lifecycle (e.g., Simple Statusnet (SIMPLE)).
    • Processing Status Profile: (Optional) Add if additional status handling is required.
    • Workflows*: Select your deployed workflow from BPA (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Reference Objects: (Optional) Add objects if you want to link the collaboration type to specific business entities.
    • Collaboration Header Fields: (Optional) Add header fields to store additional metadata.
  3. Under Configure Tabs:
    • Select the tabs that should be available for this collaboration type (e.g., Work Items, Shared Documents, Shared Product Data).
    • To add a workflow you must add the Work Items Tab.
  4. Click Save to create the collaboration type.

Step 26: Activate the Collaboration Type (Set to ‚ÄúIn Use‚Äù)

After creating your new Collaboration Type, you must activate it so it can be used within IPD.

  1. In the Collaboration Types overview, locate the entry you just created (e.g., BACT ‚Äì Build Process Automation Collaboration Type).
  2. Select the checkbox next to the ID.
  3. Click Set to ‚ÄúIn Use‚Äù in the toolbar.
    • This changes the status from In Preparation to In Use.
    • Once active, the Collaboration Type can be used in collaboration scenarios and will connect with your process.

Step 27: Create a Collaboration

Once your Collaboration Type is set to In Use, you can create a new Collaboration with the Collaboration Type.

  1. Navigate to the My Collaborations in the Collaboration launchpad.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter the required details:
    • Collaboration Type: Select the Collaboration Type you activated earlier (e.g., BACT).
    • Collaboration Name: Provide a meaningful name (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  4. Save the Collaboration.

From the My Collaborations Overview click on the arrow on the right to access a Collaboration.

Step 28: Add Workflow to the Collaboration

To connect your Collaboration instance with the BPA process, you must add the workflow that was deployed earlier.

  1. Open your Collaboration (e.g., Build Process Automation Testing).
  2. Navigate to the Work Items tab.
  3. At the bottom of the screen, click Add Workflow.

Step 29: Configure the Workflow in the Collaboration

When you add a workflow to a collaboration, you must configure its details.

  1. In the Add Workflow dialog:
    • Workflow*: Select the deployed workflow (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Title*: This is automatically filled. You can adjust if needed, but once saved, it cannot be changed.
  2. (Optional) Linked Files and Folders:
    • You can attach documents that will be shared with participants in this collaboration.
  3. (Optional) Linked Reference Object:
    • If required, assign reference objects that provide additional business context (e.g., product IDs, project numbers).
  4. (Optional) Comments:
    • Add notes or context for this workflow assignment.
  5. Click Add to link the workflow to the collaboration.

Step 30: Monitor the Workflow Execution

After adding the workflow to your collaboration, you can now start and observe the process execution.

  1. Go to the Work Items tab of your Collaboration (you may have to refresh).
  2. You will see an entry for the workflow you just added (e.g., IPD Process).
    • Running ‚Üí The workflow is active.
    • Ready ‚Üí A form or task is waiting for user action.
    • Completed ‚Üí The workflow or step is finished.
    • The Title column shows the subject defined earlier (e.g., This is my test form).
    • The Status column indicates the current execution state:

Step 31: Open ‚ÄúMy Inbox‚Äù from the Collaboration Launchpad

To act on user tasks created by your BPA workflow (e.g., the Form step), use the My Inbox app.

  1. In the Collaboration launchpad, open My Inbox.

Step 32: Complete the Form Task in My Inbox

This is the user task created by your BPA workflow. Fill it in and submit to advance the process.

  1. Enter the required data:
    • In the field Test Data (marked with an asterisk), type a value. Required fields must be filled before submission.
    • Optional: follow any informational links shown in the form (e.g., Link to sap.com).
  2. Submit the task:
    • Click Submit to send the form back to the workflow.
    • If validation errors appear, correct them and submit again.

Step 33: Verify Workflow Completion in the Collaboration

Confirm that your end-to-end flow finished successfully.

  1. In the Collaboration view, open your Collaboration
  2. Open the Work Items tab.
  3. Check the rows for your workflow (e.g., IPD Process) and its task (e.g., This is my test form).
    • Status should be Completed.
    • Assignee/Processor, Created On, and Completed On show who finished it and when.

Conclusion

Good job! You created your first process in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) and successfully deployed it in Integrated Product Development (IPD). With this foundation in place, you now have a running workflow that you can trigger, monitor, and extend.

The next step is to take your automation even further by integrating APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This will allow you to enrich your workflows with collaboration features, business data, and advanced automation scenarios. Stay tuned for my next blog post, where I will guide you through adding APIs to your SBPA processes step by step.

Alexandra Rong,
Business Process Consultant for SAP IPD,
alexandra.rong@sap.com

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI Checkbox events are not getting received imme...
entry.content:
SAP Help Checkboxes and Radio Buttons with Function Codes

Checkboxes and radio buttons without a function code behave like normal input/output fields. Clicking the object changes the contents of the field, but does not trigger the PAI event. (Clicking a pushbutton, on the other hand, always triggers the PAI event, even if it has an empty function code.)

That is why you don't get an "event" when checking a checkbox.

 

When a function code is assigned to a checkbox or radio button, clicking it not only changes the field contents, but also triggers the PAI event and places the function code in the OK CODE field.

Once a function code is assigned to a checkbox, a PAI event is triggered when the checkbox is clicked.

entry.title: Re: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and...
entry.content:
Yes how the ‚Äúcommon DC‚Äù logic actually works is when you define a common distribution channel in VOR1, you‚Äôre telling the system ‚ÄúIf master data (customer or material) is missing in DC X, look for it in the reference DC Y.‚Äù This applies to both customer and material master data ‚Äî there‚Äôs no standard way to say ‚Äúonly for materials‚Äù.

So in your example:

If you maintain a material in US01/D0, you can use it in US01/D1 or US01/D2 without creating separate sales views. The system will pull from D0. If you maintain a customer in US01/D1, you can also use it in US01/D2 if D2 points to D1 in VOR1, but in your case you don‚Äôt want that.

Because you can‚Äôt make ‚Äúcommon DC for materials only‚Äù in pure standard, you have two main options:

Option A ‚Äì Use common DC, but control customer creation

  • Keep your D0 ‚Äútechnical‚Äù DC as the reference for all others in VOR1.
  • Maintain all materials in D0 only.
  • Maintain customers only in their real DCs (D1, D2, etc.).
  • Prevent accidental customer creation in D0 by:
    • Removing authorisation for DC D0 in V_KNA1_VKO.
    • Enforcing MDG/workflow rules that reject customer creation in D0.
  • This way, the common DC works for materials, but customers are still separate in practice.

Technically, the system still could use the common DC for customers if someone created them in D0,  so you need governance.


Option B ‚Äì No common DC, automate material extension

  • Don‚Äôt use VOR1 at all.
  • Maintain material sales views in one DC (e.g. D0) and use MM17, LSMW, or Fiori mass maintenance to extend them to all other DCs automatically when a new material is created.
  • This keeps customer data completely separate by DC, and avoids the ‚ÄúSales area not defined‚Äù issue.
  • Downside: you still have multiple sales views in the database, but the creation is automated so there‚Äôs no manual effort.

If you ask me which one to choose

If governance is strong and you can lock down customer creation in the technical DC ‚Üí Option A is cleaner (only one set of material views).

If governance is weak or you want to avoid any risk of cross‚ÄëDC customer sharing ‚Üí Option B is safer (but uses automation to avoid manual work).

entry.title: Re: Using class CL_ABAP_PARALLEL for mass parallel dialog work processes
entry.content:
For information, if CL_ABAP_PARALLEL is instantiated without P_TIMEOUT (default value 0), CL_ABAP_PARALLEL will calculate a timeout for RFC tasks which depends on the context where CL_ABAP_PARALLEL is instantiated:

  • If CL_ABAP_PARALLEL runs in dialog, the RFC tasks will use the high priority timeout i.e., the one defined by the profile parameter rdisp/scheduler/prio_high/max_runtime which is by default 660 seconds.
  • If CL_ABAP_PARALLEL runs in background, the RFC tasks will use the low priority timeout i.e., the one defined by the profile parameter rdisp/scheduler/prio_low/max_runtime which is by default unlimited (no timeout).

This is documented in this question, which concerns CL_ABAP_PARALLEL: Solved: TIMEOUT dump (11 min.) for RFC in low priority (ru... - SAP Community.

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025: Elevate your learning, certification, and community experience
entry.content:
SAP TechEd (November 4‚Äì6, 2025) is just around the corner, bringing the SAP Community together for three days of learning and exchange. As a registered attendee, you‚Äôll have the chance to access a 25% discount on SAP Certification with two exam attempts ‚Äî a great opportunity to continue building your skills and showcase your expertise. 

Beyond certification, there are even more ways to get involved early. From community celebrations to hands-on learning and exclusive attendee benefits, SAP TechEd in 2025 offers multiple paths to build skills and connect with peers. 

Here are four highlights you won‚Äôt want to miss:  

Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd: September 29 ‚Äì October 24, 2025 

Kicking things off is Devtoberfest, a multi-week, developer-focused celebration leading up to SAP TechEd. Running from September 29 to October 24, Devtoberfest is an opportunity to learn, connect, and celebrate coding with the global developer community.  

Expect tutorials, challenges, and technical sessions designed to help you sharpen your skills. Participation is flexible, and every activity you complete earns points as part of the experience. It‚Äôs an engaging way to connect with fellow developers while exploring the latest SAP technologies.  

Devtoberfest also includes a contest with a grand prize: winners from past years have joined retreats and exclusive SAP TechEd experiences, and last year‚Äôs winners will be with us in Berlin. The tradition continues in 2025, with the grand prize leading to a special retreat at a future SAP TechEd event in 2026.

Discover Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd.  

Explore the Learning Zone  

 

Why wait until November to start building new skills? The learning zone for SAP TechEd is open now, packed with resources to help you get a jumpstart on your learning journey. 

Dive in to take advantage of: 

  • Over 40+ interactive value journeys and solution showcases.  
  • More than 30+ free, self-paced learning journeys aligned to SAP TechEd content tracks.  
  • Dozens of demos and real-world use cases offering hands-on experience.  

Whether you‚Äôre looking to prepare for certification, deepen your knowledge, or explore new technologies, the learning zone provides a head start.  

Explore the learning zone today to get started on your SAP TechEd journey.  

Certification Benefits for Attendees  

SAP TechEd in 2025 also brings valuable opportunities to earn your SAP Certification.  

  • Exclusive 25% Discount: All registered attendees, whether joining virtually or onsite, will receive a 25% discount on SAP Certification. This discount applies to the two exam attempts booking and supports all participants on their path towards success. 
  • Free SAP Certification at SAP TechEd in Berlin: On the final event day, in-person attendees have the chance to take a free certification exam on site.

Learn more and register now. 

These benefits make it easier than ever to validate your skills and showcase your expertise. 

Get Ready for SAP TechEd in 2025  

By joining Devtoberfest, exploring the learning zone, and taking advantage of certification offers, you can make the most of your SAP TechEd experience before the event even begins. 

This year, SAP TechEd 2025 is back as a hybrid experience‚Äîjoin us in Berlin or connect online for learning and networking opportunities. Register here for the experience that suits you best!

We‚Äôre also bringing SAP TechEd on Tour to three additional cities:

  • Louisville
  • Sydney
  • Bangalore

Don‚Äôt miss your chance to be part of the global SAP community‚Äîvirtually or on site‚Äîand immerse yourself in learning, collaboration, and inspiration.

entry.title: Re: How to Deploy/Publish RAP & Annotation based UI List...
entry.content:
Thanks, Sachin, I appreciate the update and the kind words

Since you‚Äôre blocked on the destination setup, here is a concise checklist that usually resolves BAS ‚Üí S/4HANA Public Cloud deployment issues, with the correct SAP references.

Use the documented BAS ‚Üí ABAP deployment path

In BAS, generate the Deployment Configuration (ABAP) and select your destination when prompted. SAP Help Portal-Generate Deployment Configuration ABAP

Overall flow (create app ‚Üí deploy to ABAP from BAS) is here. SAP Help Portal-Develop an SAP Fiori Application UI and Deploy it to ABAP Using SAP Business Application Studio

Create the destination correctly (BTP Cockpit)

Protocol: HTTP; Host URL = your S/4HANA Cloud host; Authentication = Oauth2 SAML Bearer Assertion; Include sap-client.

Step by step, SAP‚Äôs guide shows you the exact fields and the SAML trust setup, including how to create a Communication System in S/4HANA Cloud for your BAS subaccount.

SAP-Connect SAP Business Application Studio and SAP S/4HANA Cloud System

Two common pitfalls that cause ‚Äúauthentication/destination configuration‚Äù errors

The email address of your BTP user must match the S/4HANA Public Cloud user (SAML bearer). Mismatches cause 'Service Unavailable' or authentication errors in Fiori tools. SAP Support Portal-3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

Recheck the destination per SAP‚Äôs guidance if you see ‚Äúverify destination configuration.‚Äù

How to perform a Quick tests

In BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Destinations, run Check Connection and (if possible) open /sap/bc/adt to verify reachability.

Back in BAS, run Fiori: Deploy to ABAP and select the same destination.

If you prefer a full, click-through tutorial

End-to-end tutorial (create Fiori app in BAS and deploy to S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment). SAP-Create a SAP Fiori App and Deploy it to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ABAP Environment

Integration overview and related tasks: SAP Help Portal - Integrating the ABAP Environment with SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Once your Basis colleagues fix the destination, your current app should deploy smoothly via Fiori tools ‚Üí Deploy to ABAP. If you encounter another specific error, paste the destination properties (mask secrets) and the exact error message, and I‚Äôll identify help to fix it

All the best,
Chuma
